metadata.synopsis: Renata Bella (Holly Hunter) has no career prospects, her fiancé just broke up with her and she still lives with her parents although she is in her 30s. Desperate for direction in life, she attends a seminar on real estate sales. There she meets the brash, successful and arrogant salesman Sam Sharpe (Richard Dreyfuss). The two marry, but the brash quality that attracted her to Sam is off-putting her family, particularly with her strong-willed father, Joe (Danny Aiello).

reviews: This is both recommendation and warning: Once Around is easy to take but hard to swallow.
Dreyfuss and Hunter can't save what is a sappy and grating melodrama.
A wonderfully charming, true-to-life comedy-drama that was one of 1991's best and most overlooked films.
One of Richard Dreyfuss's best films....lovely stuff
This rather overbearing romantic comedy is by no means a disaster.
Ethnic romances from Abie's Irish Rose to Moonstruck have traveled similar ground, but few have handled the role of family in a marriage more poignantly than Once Around.
Comedy-drama has more to it than it may at first seem.
On the whole Once Around is strangely enervating, proof that family problems -- even those of fictional families -- are often best kept behind closed doors.
There is no there there, just the dead red glow of the beckoning Exit light.
The first movie in a long time to leave me speechless.
